document.title: School Curriculum and Standards Authority (Western Australia)

jurisdiction.title: School Curriculum and Standards Authority (Western Australia)

EA5C132BFFA044AA89D9EB25E9E0DE8A.description: Write consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words by representing some sounds with the appropriate letters, and blend sounds associated with letters when reading CVC words

7B84F87913FA4E1F832396C661CC6A3D.description: Segment sentences into individual words and orally blend and segment onset and rime in single syllable spoken words, and isolate, blend and manipulate phonemes in single syllable words

EF9543C95C374F678B3849CFDC98AA9A.description: Understand that words are units of meaning and can be made of more than one meaningful part

D42E522069784F59B780ED5C990D7B29.description: Know how to read and write some high-frequency words and other familiar words

9D175A37552844F29061691E68756F0C.description: Understand how to use knowledge of letters and sounds including onset and rime to spell words

A4026F8ACB9E41208A64FBE4A5B67431.description: Recognise and name all upper and lower case letters (graphemes) and know the most common sound that each letter represents

A7DE8F93E2CA4311AAB118AF05764B82.description: Recognise and generate rhyming words, alliteration patterns, syllables and sounds (phonemes) in spoken words

0C1B848CE88F4DE4A1B09F14B2C1ECB2.description: Understand the use of vocabulary in familiar contexts related to everyday experiences, personal interests and topics taught at school

F4AB7334726149D6BB0899D488F5C99C.description: Explore the different contribution of words and images to meaning in stories and informative texts

C91743A31EC748778F439E6152E467D1.description: Recognise that texts are made up of words and groups of words that make meaning

EB35A2F3FC0E4BBE95D527C3A29C4D33.description: Recognise that sentences are key units for expressing ideas

E647FD3FF44742608AC02BE322040E08.description: Understand concepts about print and screen, including how books, film and simple digital texts work, and know some features of print, for example directionality

E4E7D11D52404668A4855F7A52A2D615.description: Understand that punctuation is a feature of written text different from letters; recognise how capital letters are used for names, and that capital letters and full stops signal the beginning and end of sentences

F3309996DDC34F0DAE8D0D4DFBB58660.description: Understand that some language in written texts is unlike everyday spoken language

CDB3553E309A4C08996888824E26E526.description: Understand that texts can take many forms, can be very short (for example an exit sign) or quite long (for example an information book or a film) and that stories and informative texts have different purposes

A970F77A4E894770A879681CDC6A3FBC.description: Understand that language can be used to explore ways of expressing needs, likes and dislikes

F433E16A351E48829E1536F16F098FA7.description: Explore how language is used differently at home and school depending on the relationships between people

F8910544EF6D4C21A16462C4A3823A7F.description: Understand that English is one of many languages spoken in Australia and that different languages may be spoken by family, classmates and community
